Row.Text: There! I have taken you off the revenge list.
Vietnam stands alone. We do not need you.
Let our people share each other's burdens, and the struggle will be easier.
Our spears unite against our foes!
You know what happens to my enemies, right?
I have waited for this day for a long time. Today begins the war that will end in your destruction.
Now you are at war with Vietnam. Do you hear our trumpets? The thunder of our elephants? They are coming for you!
Your delegation has seen the beauty of Vietnam, and the fierceness of its people.
You say they come in peace, but I cannot allow any foreign infiltrators.
Vietnam's delegation approaches, bearing bird's nest soup, abalone, deer's tendon, and water from the Hàm Long well.
You cannot content yourself with ruling your own people, but you must interfere with mine as well? I shall tell the whole world of your crimes!
Look here, you snake. One day there will be a great reckoning between our peoples, and justice will be served to you.
I am Bà Triệu, the general who wears the golden robe. Welcome to Vietnam.
Welcome to Vietnam! Come and have bird's nest soup in our capital.
Yes.
Let me tell you of the citadels of Hanoi, and the dawn mist that clings to the Lake of the Returned Sword.
Welcome, guest.
You have not been plotting my destruction, so I will not plot yours.
Vietnam watches you.
Bring your elephant alongside Vietnam's! What say you?
Enough bloodshed. Let our warriors rebuild their homes.
Never! I will not bow to you.
Shall we set aside our swords?
Your people may pass, but they will be watched.
Vietnam did not live for this long just to allow foreign troops to march across our soil! No!
Will you permit my people passage?
Vietnam will not be threatened. Move your troops.
I do not have to listen to you.
Our troops are mighty and their cries terrible. We did not mean to frighten you.
Do you think you have defeated me? I will ascend to heaven, and become the immortal spirit of our resistance!
The needs of my people must come first. I cannot accept this.
Your offer will benefit my people.
Oh, prince of friends! The grasses sing of you.
I have enough friends.
Come, enjoy good wine and low-voiced songs, let us drink and let the sun and moon come and go!
Oh, prince of friends! The grasses sing of you.
You have rejected the Khan's offer of friendship. Let that sink in.
I have gathered soldiers from every corner of my realm. Be honored that I take such pains to go to war with you.
The clouds of dust on the horizon are thousands of horsemen, coming with war. Prepare yourself!
I challenged your delegates to a wrestling match. They may be a bit bruised today.
We have poetry, composite bows, and horse milk. We don't need your leftovers.
A camel train approaches your borders, bearing silks and spices, horse milk and mutton, and tales of the great Khan.
Whether you acted through ignorance or intent, the result is the same. You have annoyed me for too long, and I will no longer stand your insolence.
A day is coming when your kingdom will be consumed like grass in a wildfire. On that day, I shall rejoice. (Denounces You).
I am Kublai. In time, the whole world shall know me as emperor and great khan.
In my capital, I have arranged a wrestling match between our two strongest warriors. Come and drink fermented mare's milk with me!
Yes.
May I tell you of the pearl of the Silk Road? And might you tell me of your lands?
Greetings.
You show wisdom and might working in harmony, like well-alloyed steel.
If you cannot rule well, a better ruler will come and overthrow you. All of history teaches us this.
Let us ride together! You go first.
The bow of war is broken. Let our horses get fat.
My khans still hunger for war.
Our horses grow thin and their riders sing of home.
Your horses are welcome to ride the steppes of the Mongolian Empire and the roads of the lands the Mongolian Empire has conquered.
Borders are there for a reason. These are here to keep you out.
To be caged is to perish. If we are given borders, we die. May we pass?
Your troops obstruct the view across the steppes. Move them.
You do not give orders to a khan.
You fear us. I understand. We will ride elsewhere.
Now go; leave me to my sorrow.
The Golden Horde did not become golden with deals like this.
Yes. May profits pour in from all sides.
Oh, prince of friends! The grasses sing of you.
I have enough friends.
Come, enjoy good wine and low-voiced songs, let us drink and let the sun and moon come and go!
Oh, prince of friends! The grasses sing of you.
You have rejected the Khan's offer of friendship. Let that sink in.
I have gathered soldiers from every corner of my realm. Be honored that I take such pains to go to war with you.
The clouds of dust on the horizon are thousands of horsemen, coming with war. Prepare yourself!
I challenged your delegates to a wrestling match. They may be a bit bruised today.
We have poetry, composite bows, and horse milk. We don't need your leftovers.
A camel train approaches your borders, bearing silks and spices, horse milk and mutton, and tales of the great Khan.
Whether you acted through ignorance or intent, the result is the same. You have annoyed me for too long, and I will no longer stand your insolence.
A day is coming when your kingdom will be consumed like grass in a wildfire. On that day, I shall rejoice. (Denounces You).
I am Kublai. In time, the whole world shall know me as emperor and great khan.
In my capital, I have arranged a wrestling match between our two strongest warriors. Come and drink fermented mare's milk with me!
Yes.
May I tell you of the pearl of the Silk Road? And might you tell me of your lands?
Greetings.
You show wisdom and might working in harmony, like well-alloyed steel.
If you cannot rule well, a better ruler will come and overthrow you. All of history teaches us this.
Let us ride together! You go first.
The bow of war is broken. Let our horses get fat.
My khans still hunger for war.
Our horses grow thin and their riders sing of home.
Your horses are welcome to ride the steppes of the Mongolian Empire and the roads of the lands the Mongolian Empire has conquered.
Borders are there for a reason. These are here to keep you out.
To be caged is to perish. If we are given borders, we die. May we pass?
Your troops obstruct the view across the steppes. Move them.
You do not give orders to a khan.
You fear us. I understand. We will ride elsewhere.
Now go; leave me to my sorrow.
The Golden Horde did not become golden with deals like this.
Yes. May profits pour in from all sides.
Defender of the Homeland

Likes Civilizations who have not declared war on her. Dislikes Civilizations that have declared war on her. For these, her opinion decreases further each turn the war progresses, and this decreased opinion never decays.
Trieu likes those who have been at peace with her for a long time
Trieu dislikes those who have fought with her
Trieu likes civilizations who do not fight with her
We are friends with those who do not fight us
Fighting us is a mistake we will never forgive
Pax Mongolica
Likes Civilizations that have a strong military and high Gold yield per turn. Dislikes Civilizations with a weak military or low income.
Kublai Khan respects your strength and income
Kublai Khan heaps scorn on the weak and the poor
Kublai Khan likes rich and strong civilizations
Your strength and riches do you credit
The poor and the weak exist to be trampled underfoot
Your strength and riches do you credit
The poor and the weak exist to be trampled underfoot
